text: My only gripe with this game as of yet (aside from the crossbow) is that it's pacing is so slow. I mean I get narrative pacing blah blah, but teasing the edges of conspiracy Deus Ex, in the second of four visits to new york so far, is not making my hooked, it's making me want to shut you up so i can see the rest of the story! apparently just to get to Hong Kong (and I'm told this is less than a 1/4th of the way in) is about 14 hours give or take, and I haven't found anything, but the beginning is just, really slow, and it just doesn't grab me, at this point I'm doing it to see the "best game of all time all years", considering of those 14 hours, at least 11 of them were spent in some New York location, dicking about for NPCs for reasons I don't particularly care about. call me impatient or whatever, but if Deus ex was a TV series, this is the kind of one that you skip episodes of to get back to the interesting stuff which is blocked behind 3 hours of arbitrary boring stuff.

text: Probably because it's not true. I've played through every Deus Ex game and both Deus Ex 1 and Deus Ex HR have great music tracks. The first appeals to the cyber-punk synthetic music which was being explored in the 90s whilst HR appeals to a more epic wide-sweeping soundtrack to capture the more dramatic element of the revolution of cybernetic augmentations. They aspire to evoke different themes depending on the era which they intend to capture.

text:
Well, my only point was that people were giving him thumbs down for drawing parallels to the Matrix. Warren Spector has actually been quoted as saying that some of the concepts and visual designs are influenced by it, so his comment was valid.

And as far as Cyberpunk goes, 90% of it is influenced by Neuromancer. ;)
author: Manndroid

text: I felt that Neuromancer had a larger influence on the game, especially with the augmentations. Example: in Neuromancer people put little chips in their heads to get certain effects, like telling whether or not someone is being used like a mobile camera. In Deus Ex we have the Targeting aug that gives us information of people and things. Both can be activated at will. The only difference between the two is that augmentations are internal and the chips stick out of one's neck, behind the ear.

text:
This game is unique. Good graphics, exciting puzzles + freedom in the way of solving them : you could just rush through a group of droids, or hack their AI so they would shoot each other.

Most of all it's the dark atmosphere of a plausible near future. As an agent of the government (to simplify it) you fight "terrorist" until you discover that the world isn't as black and white as your superiors would want it to be. 
So you get to chose your "own" path in the middle of conspiracy. A must !
